Once upon a time, Painkiller, Wolfenstein and Bioshock f*cked together and then Necrovision was born...It's nice shooter with old school vibe - bosses, big levels, lots of ammo, puzzles, switches, secret places, etc... The visuals are not top notch, but fits well. Controls are little different compared to the Bioshock though - left mouse button for the left hand, right mouse button for the right hand.I said "combined", so now is the time to mention the COMBOOOS.Our hero have three types of melee attacks - kick, left hand melee and gun melee attack. The bayonettas and the shovels can be thrown at the enemies to nail them on the wall, the gas lamps exept to light the way, can be used to burn the hordes of undeads and freaky creatures. The arsenal is impressive.It's good to perform different attacks to create combo. For example - knock down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the ground and then finish him out with the pump. Or slice him with the bayonetta for the "Herr Doktor" combo.There are different "challenge rooms", which becomes avalible after beating any given level. The challenge rooms helps the player to permanently unlock different gear types to be avalible in the inventory.There are parts of the game when the player controls giant mech or even ride a dragon. Yeah, the it's total mashup of many mechanics from different games (there is even bullet time system implemented in it), but it fun to play and it works...for the most of the time.It's not AAA title, it screams "I'M A CHEAP, LOW BUDGET, SOMETIMES UGLY GAME", but it's charming in some inexplicable way. 												Necrovision is a strange game. Stuck between a myriad of styles and influences, it emerges as a blend between the atmosphere of classic world war shooters and the crazy mass murder party of games such as Painkiller, Serious Sam or Bulletstorm. The overall result is highly personal and depends heavily on your mindset: don't go into this game expecting an AAA shooter. You'll find cringeworthy cutscenes, amateurish voice acting, a pixelated GUI and weird bugs all around.However, as soon as you get past its imperfections, you'll be playing a pretty crazy and fun game with a (surprisingly!) relatively readable storyline, zombie beheading, dragons, huge boss fights and lots of other nonsense ♥♥♥♥ happening in WWI. One of the biggest surprises was level design, which, although relatively linear, is huge, well planned enough, often aesthetically pleasing and with a very classic feel and pace.On less positive points, the combo system is pretty bland and doesn't really feel well-implemented (although it can be fun). The weapons are also sub-par: the historical limitations are understandable, but for a game this crazy, they often slow the action to a crawl as you painstakingly bolt your rifle after every shot fighting giant demon things. Health is also a bit weird: medkits exist and are pretty abundant but are close to useless since your health automatically recharges up to about 75%; which breaks some of the classic appeal in my view.Overally, Necrovision is a pretty fun experience if you're willing to forget its technical shortcomings and accept its particular brand of insanity. 7.5/10

												One of the wierdest shooters I've ever played. If I had to describe it as briefly as possible I'd say it's DooM set during WWI, with some LOTR mixed in because kraut zombies wasn't strange enough. The first half of the game is a relatively standard period shooter with bullet-sponge opponents; These levels are well designed but drag on a bit. The second half of Necrovision is where things start to shine, as you find yourself dropped into the middle of a compelling underground fantasy realm populated by imaginative (and truly chilling) monsters like gas-mask spiders, flamethrower rat-men, ninja vampires, angry spirits and yes, DRAGONS. The needlessly convoluted story concerns the subjugation of this under-world by demonic forces, who are now spilling over onto the surface. It is here you receive an entirely new set of weapons and a nifty melee super-gauntlet that can be charged with the souls of fallen enemies to unleash powerful explosive attacks. I wish some of the opening missions could be shortened or cut completely to make way for this part of the game, as no doubt many players will be turned off by their first-impression of Necrovision before having a chance to experience the good stuff.Technically the game is rough around the edges, with some maddening difficulty spikes, but worth it for shooter enthusiasts in search of an original premise and oppressive atmosphere.

Hitbox, view, weapons, protagonist style, enemy attacks, sounds - so many thing could be improved. Do you really want to play it? Play it. Are you curious if it's generally worth playing? The answer is a really, really solid no.TLDR about mechanics: weapon selection is unreliable, headbob is super nauseating and actively prevents gameplay, level and enemy design is boring + last levels is artifically hard with deadly pitfalls and HORDES or knockback enemies. These make the game an unfair chore instead of a fun, or challenging shooter. The story... let's say it's unique. WW1 happens, then zombies, wraiths, trolls (?)...  a dragon appears, later you defeat mandatory evil german scientist's giant scorpion tank with your walking tank (yes.), only to later realize the vampires, living underground are corrupted by the demons whom Zimmermann allowed into the world, so you have to fight machinegun-wielding vampires, later ratmen equipped iwth flamethrowers while throwing fireballs and stakes out of your magical weapon, only to fight Satan in hell after taking a flying trip with a dragon. YES. THIS IS THE STORY.  I don't know what they were tripping on, but let's just ignore this....Let's say the ideas are okay. But then I'm still left with a game where I can have 6 items cycling on my key 1, later I have magics on 1 (really bad idea, only forward cycling) AND my one-armed guns, and I have to cycle all 4 with my mouse wheel. Meanwhile keys 6-9 are not even used. What the hell....  and if weapon changing troubles wouldn't be enough, there are a lot of melee enemies who attack by dashing "through" you, as they constantly clip though you. They shriek, they sometimes not even visible because they are IN you, and you are also experiencing the worst headbob I've ever seen. Using submachine gun in iron sights is a trip for seizure-land, and even just ogres being around means a MASSIVE shaking effect that means useless aiming. And as you fight mostly undeads, headshots are a nice way to kill, otherwise it takes 3-5 times more shots. Now if you add this info together that they can stunlock you because you can't aim...  Then on the final levels when you can even fall down into lava they introduce enemies that jump at you, knocking you back super-hard (while using a stock sound asset), because there are no way to make those levels be more hated than that. If not for the bet/promise that I will finish the game, I would have stopped around chapter 2-3 out of 12...it would have been a definitely better decision.

												Quick Summary: Action / Horror First Person Shooter with mostly World War 1 weapons, though that changes about half way through the game. The graphics are decent for an indie game and gameplay is pretty basic shooting with partially regenerating health so you can run through large portions of the game.You play Simon, an American soldier in Europe fighting the Germans in World War 1, but you quickly encounter far more dangerous enemies as the dead rise and demonic forces appear out of thin air. As you sacrifice your humanity and progress deeper and deeper underground, you find the ancient world of the vampires, who look like people in heavy bug armor (watch out for their vampire kung fu). For ages the vampires have held back the demons from invading, and now it’s up to Simon to do what they no longer can: Enter the portal to Hell and defeat the demon lords.Right from the start of the game you’ll get some pretty pathetic World War 1 guns and throwable weapons. Most of the enemies in the game have enough life that it takes a few seconds of shooting to kill them. That means any more than 3 or 4 enemies at once can be a threat to you, especially when you run into the big dudes who actually run faster than you and take about 5 clips of ammo to kill. Like a lot of modern games, if you can avoid taking damage for a few seconds, your life will partially regenerate (up to about 60%). This means you can run past about half the enemies in the game (much harder in later levels with teleporting enemies). An additional tool in your bag of tricks is the “adrenaline” meter which you charge up by killing enemies. The adrenaline can be used to temporarily slow down time, making it easier to avoid enemy attacks (or run away like me). If you take enough damage to kill you, and you have a full adrenaline meter, the time slow will activate automatically and you’ll actually become invincible during the effect. Unfortunately, during the time slow, your attacking and reloading is slowed down too, so don’t think you can just use the opportunity to blast everyone. Additionally, when you’ve started your descent underground you’ll acquire a special weapon with magical attacks (shadowhand). It’s not as cool as it sounds, but it adds to your arsenal.Pros:+I enjoy horror shooters (like Jericho) and despite having mixed ratings, the story is ok.+This is a straightforward run and gun. There isn’t that much puzzle solving so if you just want to blast some enemies, you can do that. You have a little compass on your HUD that points you which direction you need to go.Cons:-The game crashes occasionally for no apparent reason. Also, I wasn’t able to Alt+Tab out of the game without the game freezing. There’s a bug causing blurry vision, but that can be fixed with a command line addition.-The little cut scenes between levels are weird. Not only is the subtitling occasionally wrong, but they show and say things that don’t make much sense relative to what has happened in the gameplay. This is likely due to the game’s developers not being native English speakers.Overall, the game is a mostly brainless shooter and if you’ve played the Serious Sam or Painkiller games, you should have an idea what to expect. The game isn’t awesome, but it’s not completely horrible either. 6/10

YouTube™ Video: Cheap PC Games: NecroVision Review 

			Views: 853		

			http://store.steampowered.com/app/7860/ https://www.indiegala.com/store/product/necrovision/7860 Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Little_B_Gaming		

For this review I wanted to see how many games are dedicated to WWI. What I found  is they are not many and not too popular. Valiant Hearts and Verdun are most well known I think. There are few grand strategies, but i'm not in to them. The reason i started with this is NecroVision take place in WWI setting and this was the only thing I could think of to start the review.You take the role of Simon Buckner, young american who join the British army to fight germans in 1916. After an ambush and the following fierce battle, everything for our hero turns upside down. Simon encounters supernatural phenomenon and realize that greater evil threatens to wipe humanity. To a certain degree it's the germans fault. They never learn not to play with fire. The story is not bad, it kept me interested through the whole game, but it's not memorable enough. You have to save Earth from germans, vampires, demons and whole other bunch of creatures. The good thig in the story is it takes to great locations.Let me take a step back and look at the the settings. Rebindable keys, HUD and crosshair opacity are few of the good things in here. But in sound is missing speech slider. In some places people speak so quietly, I can bearly hear them. Subtitles help to understand what are they saying, but they in some places are not displayed. In video options you can change a lot of things – textures for weapons, people, envoirment. Also you have render quality, dynamic shadows and so on. But even if everything is on max settings the games is not a good looker.The dev try and succeed in putting enough mechanics in the gameplay to differentiate from other FPSs. Not all are entirly original. When you kill enemy in non-traditional style, you are rewarded with Adrenaline and Fury. Adrenaline is basically bullet-time and later is used for one more thing. Later for it. Non-traditional ways for killing reminds of Bulletstorm, but here they are not that creative. Headshots with different weapons, kicking, melee and so on. When you manage to chain few combos, you gain Fury level, which in turns leads to, for the first few level, electricity coming from you and hitting enemies. For even higher level – incinerating them. For reaching maximum Fury, be on a lookout for hidden vampire artefacts. Each found increases one level. It's so satysfing to melee a group of bad guys and incinerate them.NecroVision is FPS. And what you do in this type of game? Shooting and blasting enemies. How is the shooting? It's good. Weapons have arcade feel to them. They don't have recoil, but they also don't have Quake-like accuracy. If enemies are far away , you have to burst, because crosshair widens and the gun become less acurate. Weapons in 1/3 of the game more or less represent the time period the game takes place. Two pistols, rifle, sniper, rocket launcher, shotgun, heavy and light machine gun. These weapons are used in abovementioned 1/3 of the game. After that the game takes hard turn and starts to get more interesting. You get Shadowhand, SMG, shotgun, rocket launcher, and flamethrower. One of them raises curiosity. It's Shadowhand. It's metal glove with Wolverine-like claws. You can use it for melee or cast spells – fireballs, iron rods and freezing. All are useful. Shadowhand have one one more ability – raising the dead. When Adrenalin is on it's maximum stand to nearby fallen enemie and ressurect him to help you fight.There is more. You can dual-wield pistols and machine guns. You are less accurate, but in close range is so satisfying to mow enemies down. In your right hand you can equip a pistol and in your left you can put another pistol, bayonet, shovel, granade, dynamite and gas lamp for setting enemies on fire. With shovel and bayonet you can melee or throw them. I killed a lot of enemies that way. Almost every murder gives you adrenaline.There is a sprint button. Except for fast movement, you can use it with combination from melee and a gun to knock down a group of enemies. This and kicking are the best course of action if bad guys surround you.I intentionally missed few interesting things, that will happen. I don't want to spoil everything, when the game turns 180.Restoring health is done in two different ways. Generally, half of it is regenerating and for the other half you have to find med packs. This is through the first 1/3 of the game, which I will continue to mention. After that you will restore it by collecting red orbs from dead enemies or finding them in hidden places or breaking the surroundings.When you are about to die, you get The Last Chance. Everything slows down to a crawl for a few seconds and you have manage to get away or die.The level design through the 1/3 of the game are okay. Trenches, castles, dungeons, all standard stuff. But (there is a big but here) when you past that 1/3, the gets more interesting. Better and wider level design, better atmosphere. Gothic dungeons created from forgotten and vanished civilization, full with strange machines, electricity coming from tesla coils, dungeons filled with lava, strange railroad, leading to some uncharted and dark places, deep in the bowls of the earth. Here creativity of the developer shines. Great level desing!In almost every level there are secrets to be found. Except the abovementioned vampire artefacts, there are also weapons, ammo, letters and golden chests to be found.The sound here is not great. As I mentioned in the beginning some voice actors can barely heard and this is design flaw, because this is at certain places. The voice acting is good, but I don't like the main character voice and don't get me started with the one liners. They are not that good or original and you will hear them over and over again through the hole game. Music is almost absent. When is present it's good, but it's so rare to hear it. There is some ambient music and it's contribute for the atmoshpere, but it's not enough. The game needs more tracks and the music have to be played more often. Enemies are fairly diverse. I know i'm repeating my self, but during the first 1/3 of the game most of them will be germans and zombies and few bosses. Eventually and gradually, new enemies will apear. Masked people that shoot you, other that make some kung fu kicks, when you are closer to them, imps, dragons and other flying creatures, two types of ogres and so on. I don't know what type of creatures are all of them, so I make up their species to get you an idea to some degree how they look. I almost had no problems with all enemies, unless they surround me. The ogres gave me headache, because they are fast and do a lot of damage.Almost everything I said until now is what I liked about the game. However, there are few things I don't like and I think it's worth to mention them. Non of them are game breaking. One of them is the AI, when you ressurect someone. It's dumb as brick, always falling behind, you have to walk slowly and babysite them. This makes the ressurection useless. You can also see flickering textures on buildings. As a whole the game is not a good looker. Sometimes I didn't know where to go, I was confused by the level design. Some times I can jump over a fence, others I can't. Not always was clear where to go, but this maybe my fault. There tiny little bugs, but naybe the biggest problem is the first 1/3 of the game. It's fun, but it's just okay. But after that everything gets better – level design, guns, abilities, atmoshpere, enemies, everything! I get it from storytelling point, but some players maybe be turn off by this. Be patient and you will granted with awesome moments. As a whole it's rough around the edges, but entertaing. The game reminds me of Return to Castle Wolfenstein and Painkiller, this is a good thing. It's not as polished as them, but you can always do worse. I had fun, so I recommend it.

												NecroVisioN is one of many old-school games out there. But it's not a generic arcade shooter. There is something that differs NecroVisioN from other shooters, modern included.Story and setting:  The game is set in 1916, during the First World War. You play as Simon Bukner, a british trooper whose destiny is about to change... The game starts in generic trench warfare scenario, but later we will find out that there are much worse enemies than germans. Though, the storytelling is pretty confusing - that's the only flaw.  Overall story score: 4/5Gameplay:Gameplay and mechanics in this game are brilliant. There are two-hand weapon mechanics, enemy limb damage mechanics and even great close combat mechanics. For example, you can grab a knife and a Luger, a demonic hand and a Luger, and much more. Enemies greatly react to damage - you can shoot his leg off to make him crawl away in despair. As in every old-school shooter, there are secrets scattered around the level. Talking about the levels, they are huge, taking an hour to pass, which is definetly an advantage.  Overall gameplay score: 5/5Graphics:The game is built on NecroEngine, which is a modified version of PainEngine used in PainKiller. The engine provides an amazing picture quality: the effects are juicy and loud and the designs are great. Though, graphics in this game are pretty lame in comparison to nowadays standarts - "soap" textures and "rubber" people. Overall graphics score: 3/5 (personal: 5/5) Design: Design is what gives this game an awesome feeling. Gasmask-wearing spiders; barbed wire-coiled, mutilated germans and vampires, gigantic underground strongholds and much more. Overall design score: 5/5 To conclude, I definetly recommend this game to you if you need quality gameplay. Overall score: 4/5, one of the best old-school games out there.

But even if everything is on max settings the games is not a good looker.The dev try and succeed in putting enough mechanics in the gameplay to differentiate from other FPSs. Not all are entirly original. When you kill enemy in non-traditional style, you are rewarded with Adrenaline and Fury. Adrenaline is basically bullet-time and later is used for one more thing. Later for it. Non-traditional ways for killing reminds of Bulletstorm, but here they are not that creative. Headshots with different weapons, kicking, melee and so on. When you manage to chain few combos, you gain Fury level, which in turns leads to, for the first few level, electricity coming from you and hitting enemies. For even higher level – incinerating them. For reaching maximum Fury, be on a lookout for hidden vampire artefacts. Each found increases one level. It's so satysfing to melee a group of bad guys and incinerate them.NecroVision is FPS. And what you do in this type of game? Shooting and blasting enemies. How is the shooting? It's good. Weapons have arcade feel to them. They don't have recoil, but they also don't have Quake-like accuracy. If enemies are far away , you have to burst, because crosshair widens and the gun become less acurate. Weapons in 1/3 of the game more or less represent the time period the game takes place. Two pistols, rifle, sniper, rocket launcher, shotgun, heavy and light machine gun. These weapons are used in abovementioned 1/3 of the game. After that the game takes hard turn and starts to get more interesting. You get Shadowhand, SMG, shotgun, rocket launcher, and flamethrower. One of them raises curiosity. It's Shadowhand. It's metal glove with Wolverine-like claws. You can use it for melee or cast spells – fireballs, iron rods and freezing. All are useful. Shadowhand have one one more ability – raising the dead. When Adrenalin is on it's maximum stand to nearby fallen enemie and ressurect him to help you fight.There is more. You can dual-wield pistols and machine guns. You are less accurate, but in close range is so satisfying to mow enemies down. In your right hand you can equip a pistol and in your left you can put another pistol, bayonet, shovel, granade, dynamite and gas lamp for setting enemies on fire. With shovel and bayonet you can melee or throw them. I killed a lot of enemies that way. Almost every murder gives you adrenaline.There is a sprint button. Except for fast movement, you can use it with combination from melee and a gun to knock down a group of enemies. This and kicking are the best course of action if bad guys surround you.I intentionally missed few interesting things, that will happen. I don't want to spoil everything, when the game turns 180.Restoring health is done in two different ways. Generally, half of it is regenerating and for the other half you have to find med packs. This is through the first 1/3 of the game, which I will continue to mention. After that you will restore it by collecting red orbs from dead enemies or finding them in hidden places or breaking the surroundings.When you are about to die, you get The Last Chance. Everything slows down to a crawl for a few seconds and you have manage to get away or die.The level design through the 1/3 of the game are okay. Trenches, castles, dungeons, all standard stuff. But (there is a big but here) when you past that 1/3, the gets more interesting. Better and wider level design, better atmosphere. Gothic dungeons created from forgotten and vanished civilization, full with strange machines, electricity coming from tesla coils, dungeons filled with lava, strange railroad, leading to some uncharted and dark places, deep in the bowls of the earth. Here creativity of the developer shines. Great level desing!In almost every level there are secrets to be found. Except the abovementioned vampire artefacts, there are also weapons, ammo, letters and golden chests to be found.The sound here is not great. As I mentioned in the beginning some voice actors can barely heard and this is design flaw, because this is at certain places. The voice acting is good, but I don't like the main character voice and don't get me started with the one liners. They are not that good or original and you will hear them over and over again through the hole game. Music is almost absent. When is present it's good, but it's so rare to hear it. There is some ambient music and it's contribute for the atmoshpere, but it's not enough. The game needs more tracks and the music have to be played more often. Enemies are fairly diverse. I know i'm repeating my self, but during the first 1/3 of the game most of them will be germans and zombies and few bosses. Eventually and gradually, new enemies will apear. Masked people that shoot you, other that make some kung fu kicks, when you are closer to them, imps, dragons and other flying creatures, two types of ogres and so on. I don't know what type of creatures are all of them, so I make up their species to get you an idea to some degree how they look. I almost had no problems with all enemies, unless they surround me. The ogres gave me headache, because they are fast and do a lot of damage.Almost everything I said until now is what I liked about the game. However, there are few things I don't like and I think it's worth to mention them. Non of them are game breaking. One of them is the AI, when you ressurect someone. It's dumb as brick, always falling behind, you have to walk slowly and babysite them. This makes the ressurection useless. You can also see flickering textures on buildings. As a whole the game is not a good looker. Sometimes I didn't know where to go, I was confused by the level design. Some times I can jump over a fence, others I can't. Not always was clear where to go, but this maybe my fault. There tiny little bugs, but naybe the biggest problem is the first 1/3 of the game. It's fun, but it's just okay. But after that everything gets better – level design, guns, abilities, atmoshpere, enemies, everything! I get it from storytelling point, but some players maybe be turn off by this. Be patient and you will granted with awesome moments. As a whole it's rough around the edges, but entertaing. The game reminds me of Return to Castle Wolfenstein and Painkiller, this is a good thing. It's not as polished as them, but you can always do worse. I had fun, so I recommend it.

												This is one of those times I wish I could give a neutral rating. It’s definitely not one of the greatest FPS games, but it certainly isn’t the worst. You play as Simon Bukner, an American Soldier in The British Army, fighting against the Germans during World War I. The game takes you through the battle of the Somme, underground world of vampires, and eventually Hell. During the course of the game Simon uncovers a war between vampires and demons,  and earth’s fate hangs in the balance.  The plot itself is interesting but does fall flat in some areas, and has weak narrative. Although it does have weak narrative, you generally feel progression as you play through game, and it often feels like you are working towards a goal. Unfortunately more often than not, you aren’t quite sure what that overall goal is, or why you’re doing it. The dialog and voice acting is subpar and is sometimes laughable due to it’s corniness. A side not on voice acting, for the last few chapters of the game, all of the voice acting was in Spanish or Italian (excuse my ignorance) but the cutscenes were in English; it was never explained why, or at least I didn’t see why. Funny thing is, is that I didn’t mind at all, I felt the language fit really well and the voice acting was nice.   I did really enjoy the combat in Necrovision,  it had a very old school feel to it, and a great dual-wield system The weapon selection was adequate, although during the latter half of the game, just a small handful of guns was available, and you could no longer get ammo for the weapons you had found on earth. The enemies you fought were varied, you come across German soldiers, zombies, ghosts, vampires, and demons. And all kinds of hideous abominations of said enemies. Boss fights were fun and were generally large bosses, but took little strategy.   I wanted this game to have a “neutral” rating was because it isn’t a game I would ever go out of my way to recommend to a friend, and there are a lot of other shooters I would recommend before this one. But it’s positive because I did have some fun mowing down some zombies and demons and spouting some cheezy one-liners
